content:
Cori is broadly interested in marine conservation ecology, with an emphasis on merging basic science with applied issues and public engagement. She comes to Bren from the University of North Carolina’s Institute of Marine Sciences, where she worked on multiple projects related to the population ecology of estuarine fishes and natural history of biogenic habitats. She’s particularly interested in species-habitat interactions and the value of coastal systems as nursery habitat for commercially and recreationally important species. Her past research has explored diverse marine systems (ranging from North Carolina estuaries to Caribbean and Pacific islands to Australian bays), and a wide set of ecological issues (e.g., seagrass and marsh ecology, population structure/dynamics, fisheries, sea turtle and dolphin conservation biology).
As a PhD student at Bren, Cori hopes to work to better understand human impacts on marine systems, and plans to use an interdisciplinary approach to explore creative strategies for natural resource management.
summary: Cori is broadly interested in marine conservation ecology, with an emphasis on merging basic science with applied issues and public engagement. She comes to Bren from the University of North Carolina’s Institute of Marine Sciences, where she worked on multiple projects related to the population ecology of estuarine fishes and natural history of biogenic habitats. She’s particularly interested in species-habitat interactions and the value of coastal systems as nursery habitat for commercially and recreationally important species.
title: Cori Lopazanski

content:
Flexibility This feature can be used for publishing content such as:
 Online courses Project or software documentation Tutorials  The courses folder may be renamed. For example, we can rename it to docs for software/project documentation or tutorials for creating an online course.
Delete tutorials To remove these pages, delete the courses folder and see below to delete the associated menu link.
Update site menu After renaming or deleting the courses folder, you may wish to update any [[main]] menu links to it by editing your menu configuration at config/_default/menus.toml.
For example, if you delete this folder, you can remove the following from your menu configuration:
[[main]] name = "Courses" url = "courses/" weight = 50  Or, if you are creating a software documentation site, you can rename the courses folder to docs and update the associated Courses menu configuration to:
[[main]] name = "Docs" url = "docs/" weight = 50  Update the docs menu If you use the docs layout, note that the name of the menu in the front matter should be in the form [menu.X] where X is the folder name. Hence, if you rename the courses/example/ folder, you should also rename the menu definitions in the front matter of files within courses/example/ from [menu.example] to [menu.<NewFolderName>].
summary: Learn how to use Academic's docs layout for publishing online courses, software documentation, and tutorials.
title: Overview

title: Example Page 2

content:
Click on the Slides button above to view the built-in slides feature.   Slides can be added in a few ways:
 Create slides using Academic’s Slides feature and link using slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file Upload an existing slide deck to static/ and link using url_slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file Embed your slides (e.g. Google Slides) or presentation video on this page using shortcodes.  Further talk details can easily be added to this page using Markdown and $\rm \LaTeX$ math code.
summary: An example talk using Academic's Markdown slides feature.
title: Example Talk

content:
Academic is designed to give technical content creators a seamless experience. You can focus on the content and Academic handles the rest.
Highlight your code snippets, take notes on math classes, and draw diagrams from textual representation.
On this page, you’ll find some examples of the types of technical content that can be rendered with Academic.
Examples Code Academic supports a Markdown extension for highlighting code syntax. You can enable this feature by toggling the highlight option in your config/_default/params.toml file.
```python import pandas as pd data = pd.read_csv("data.csv") data.head() ```  renders as
import pandas as pd data = pd.read_csv("data.csv") data.head()  Math Academic supports a Markdown extension for $\LaTeX$ math. You can enable this feature by toggling the math option in your config/_default/params.toml file.
To render inline or block math, wrap your LaTeX math with $...$ or $$...$$, respectively.
Example math block:
$$\gamma_{n} = \frac{ \left | \left (\mathbf x_{n} - \mathbf x_{n-1} \right )^T \left [\nabla F (\mathbf x_{n}) - \nabla F (\mathbf x_{n-1}) \right ] \right |} {\left \|\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n}) - \nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n-1}) \right \|^2}$$  renders as
$$\gamma_{n} = \frac{ \left | \left (\mathbf x_{n} - \mathbf x_{n-1} \right )^T \left [\nabla F (\mathbf x_{n}) - \nabla F (\mathbf x_{n-1}) \right ] \right |}{\left |\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n}) - \nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n-1}) \right |^2}$$
Example inline math $\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n})$ renders as $\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n})$.
Example multi-line math using the \\ math linebreak:
$$f(k;p_0^*) = \begin{cases} p_0^* & \text{if }k=1, \\ 1-p_0^* & \text {if }k=0.\end{cases}$$  renders as
$$f(k;p_0^*) = \begin{cases} p_0^* & \text{if }k=1, \
1-p_0^* & \text {if }k=0.\end{cases}$$
Diagrams Academic supports a Markdown extension for diagrams. You can enable this feature by toggling the diagram option in your config/_default/params.toml file or by adding diagram: true to your page front matter.
An example flowchart:
```mermaid graph TD A[Hard] -->|Text| B(Round) B --> C{Decision} C -->|One| D[Result 1] C -->|Two| E[Result 2] ```  renders as
graph TD A[Hard] -->|Text| B(Round) B --> C{Decision} C -->|One| D[Result 1] C -->|Two| E[Result 2]  An example sequence diagram:
```mermaid sequenceDiagram Alice->>John: Hello John, how are you? loop Healthcheck John->>John: Fight against hypochondria end Note right of John: Rational thoughts! John-->>Alice: Great! John->>Bob: How about you? Bob-->>John: Jolly good! ```  renders as
sequenceDiagram Alice->>John: Hello John, how are you? loop Healthcheck John->>John: Fight against hypochondria end Note right of John: Rational thoughts! John-->>Alice: Great! John->>Bob: How about you? Bob-->>John: Jolly good!  An example Gantt diagram:
```mermaid gantt section Section Completed :done, des1, 2014-01-06,2014-01-08 Active :active, des2, 2014-01-07, 3d Parallel 1 : des3, after des1, 1d Parallel 2 : des4, after des1, 1d Parallel 3 : des5, after des3, 1d Parallel 4 : des6, after des4, 1d ```  renders as
gantt section Section Completed :done, des1, 2014-01-06,2014-01-08 Active :active, des2, 2014-01-07, 3d Parallel 1 : des3, after des1, 1d Parallel 2 : des4, after des1, 1d Parallel 3 : des5, after des3, 1d Parallel 4 : des6, after des4, 1d  An example class diagram:
```mermaid classDiagram Class01 <|-- AveryLongClass : Cool <<interface>> Class01 Class09 --> C2 : Where am i? Class09 --* C3 Class09 --|> Class07 Class07 : equals() Class07 : Object[] elementData Class01 : size() Class01 : int chimp Class01 : int gorilla class Class10 { <<service>> int id size() } ```  renders as
classDiagram Class01 <|-- AveryLongClass : Cool <<interface>> Class01 Class09 --> C2 : Where am i? Class09 --* C3 Class09 --|> Class07 Class07 : equals() Class07 : Object[] elementData Class01 : size() Class01 : int chimp Class01 : int gorilla class Class10 { <<service>> int id size() }  An example state diagram:
```mermaid stateDiagram [*] --> Still Still --> [*] Still --> Moving Moving --> Still Moving --> Crash Crash --> [*] ```  renders as
stateDiagram [*] --> Still Still --> [*] Still --> Moving Moving --> Still Moving --> Crash Crash --> [*]  Todo lists You can even write your todo lists in Academic too:
- [x] Write math example - [x] Write diagram example - [ ] Do something else  renders as
 Write math example Write diagram example Do something else  Tables Represent your data in tables:
| First Header | Second Header | | ------------- | ------------- | | Content Cell | Content Cell | | Content Cell | Content Cell |  renders as
   First Header Second Header     Content Cell Content Cell   Content Cell Content Cell    Asides Academic supports a shortcode for asides, also referred to as notices, hints, or alerts. By wrapping a paragraph in {{% alert note %}} ... {{% /alert %}}, it will render as an aside.
{{% alert note %}} A Markdown aside is useful for displaying notices, hints, or definitions to your readers. {{% /alert %}}  renders as
 A Markdown aside is useful for displaying notices, hints, or definitions to your readers.   Did you find this page helpful? Consider sharing it 🙌
summary:
Academic is designed to give technical content creators a seamless experience. You can focus on the content and Academic handles the rest.
Highlight your code snippets, take notes on math classes, and draw diagrams from textual representation.
On this page, you’ll find some examples of the types of technical content that can be rendered with Academic.
Examples Code Academic supports a Markdown extension for highlighting code syntax. You can enable this feature by toggling the highlight option in your config/_default/params.
title: Writing technical content in Academic

content: Click the Slides button above to demo Academic’s Markdown slides feature.   Supplementary notes can be added here, including code and math.
summary: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Duis posuere tellus ac convallis placerat. Proin tincidunt magna sed ex sollicitudin condimentum.
title: An example preprint / working paper

content:
from IPython.core.display import Image Image('https://www.python.org/static/community_logos/python-logo-master-v3-TM-flattened.png')  print("Welcome to Academic!")  Welcome to Academic!  Install Python and JupyterLab Install Anaconda which includes Python 3 and JupyterLab.
Alternatively, install JupyterLab with pip3 install jupyterlab.
Create or upload a Jupyter notebook Run the following commands in your Terminal, substituting <MY-WEBSITE-FOLDER> and <SHORT-POST-TITLE> with the file path to your Academic website folder and a short title for your blog post (use hyphens instead of spaces), respectively:
mkdir -p <MY-WEBSITE-FOLDER>/content/post/<SHORT-POST-TITLE>/ cd <MY-WEBSITE-FOLDER>/content/post/<SHORT-POST-TITLE>/ jupyter lab index.ipynb  The jupyter command above will launch the JupyterLab editor, allowing us to add Academic metadata and write the content.
Edit your post metadata The first cell of your Jupter notebook will contain your post metadata (front matter).
In Jupter, choose Markdown as the type of the first cell and wrap your Academic metadata in three dashes, indicating that it is YAML front matter:
--- title: My post's title date: 2019-09-01 # Put any other Academic metadata here... ---  Edit the metadata of your post, using the documentation as a guide to the available options.
To set a featured image, place an image named featured into your post’s folder.
For other tips, such as using math, see the guide on writing content with Academic.
Convert notebook to Markdown jupyter nbconvert index.ipynb --to markdown --NbConvertApp.output_files_dir=.  Example This post was created with Jupyter. The orginal files can be found at https://github.com/gcushen/hugo-academic/tree/master/exampleSite/content/post/jupyter
summary: Learn how to blog in Academic using Jupyter notebooks
title: Display Jupyter Notebooks with Academic

content:
Create slides in Markdown with Academic Academic | Documentation
 Features  Efficiently write slides in Markdown 3-in-1: Create, Present, and Publish your slides Supports speaker notes Mobile friendly slides   Controls  Next: Right Arrow or Space Previous: Left Arrow Start: Home Finish: End Overview: Esc Speaker notes: S Fullscreen: F Zoom: Alt + Click PDF Export: E   Code Highlighting Inline code: variable
Code block:
porridge = "blueberry" if porridge == "blueberry": print("Eating...")   Math In-line math: $x + y = z$
Block math:
$$ f\left( x \right) = ;\frac{{2\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x - 4} \right)}}{{\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x + 1} \right)}} $$
 Fragments Make content appear incrementally
{{% fragment %}} One {{% /fragment %}} {{% fragment %}} **Two** {{% /fragment %}} {{% fragment %}} Three {{% /fragment %}}  Press Space to play!
One  Two  Three 
 A fragment can accept two optional parameters:
 class: use a custom style (requires definition in custom CSS) weight: sets the order in which a fragment appears   Speaker Notes Add speaker notes to your presentation
{{% speaker_note %}} - Only the speaker can read these notes - Press `S` key to view {{% /speaker_note %}}  Press the S key to view the speaker notes!
 Only the speaker can read these notes Press S key to view    Themes  black: Black background, white text, blue links (default) white: White background, black text, blue links league: Gray background, white text, blue links beige: Beige background, dark text, brown links sky: Blue background, thin dark text, blue links    night: Black background, thick white text, orange links serif: Cappuccino background, gray text, brown links simple: White background, black text, blue links solarized: Cream-colored background, dark green text, blue links   Custom Slide Customize the slide style and background
{{< slide background-image="/img/boards.jpg" >}} {{< slide background-color="#0000FF" >}} {{< slide class="my-style" >}}   Custom CSS Example Let’s make headers navy colored.
Create assets/css/reveal_custom.css with:
.reveal section h1, .reveal section h2, .reveal section h3 { color: navy; }   Questions? Ask
Documentation
summary: An introduction to using Academic's Slides feature.
title: Slides

content:
Create a free website with Academic using Markdown, Jupyter, or RStudio. Choose a beautiful color theme and build anything with the Page Builder - over 40 widgets, themes, and language packs included!
Check out the latest demo of what you’ll get in less than 10 minutes, or view the showcase of personal, project, and business sites.
 👉 Get Started 📚 View the documentation 💬 Ask a question on the forum 👥 Chat with the community 🐦 Twitter: @source_themes @GeorgeCushen #MadeWithAcademic 💡 Request a feature or report a bug ⬆️ Updating? View the Update Guide and Release Notes ❤ Support development of Academic:  ☕️ Donate a coffee 💵 Become a backer on Patreon 🖼️ Decorate your laptop or journal with an Academic sticker 👕 Wear the T-shirt 👩‍💻 Contribute       Academic is mobile first with a responsive design to ensure that your site looks stunning on every device.   Key features:
 Page builder - Create anything with widgets and elements Edit any type of content - Blog posts, publications, talks, slides, projects, and more! Create content in Markdown, Jupyter, or RStudio Plugin System - Fully customizable color and font themes Display Code and Math - Code highlighting and LaTeX math supported Integrations - Google Analytics, Disqus commenting, Maps, Contact Forms, and more! Beautiful Site - Simple and refreshing one page design Industry-Leading SEO - Help get your website found on search engines and social media Media Galleries - Display your images and videos with captions in a customizable gallery Mobile Friendly - Look amazing on every screen with a mobile friendly version of your site Multi-language - 15+ language packs including English, 中文, and Português Multi-user - Each author gets their own profile page Privacy Pack - Assists with GDPR Stand Out - Bring your site to life with animation, parallax backgrounds, and scroll effects One-Click Deployment - No servers. No databases. Only files.  Themes Academic comes with automatic day (light) and night (dark) mode built-in. Alternatively, visitors can choose their preferred mode - click the sun/moon icon in the top right of the Demo to see it in action! Day/night mode can also be disabled by the site admin in params.toml.
Choose a stunning theme and font for your site. Themes are fully customizable.
Ecosystem  Academic Admin: An admin tool to import publications from BibTeX or import assets for an offline site Academic Scripts: Scripts to help migrate content to new versions of Academic  Install You can choose from one of the following four methods to install:
 one-click install using your web browser (recommended) install on your computer using Git with the Command Prompt/Terminal app install on your computer by downloading the ZIP files install on your computer with RStudio  Then personalize and deploy your new site.
Updating View the Update Guide.
Feel free to star the project on Github to help keep track of updates.
License Copyright 2016-present George Cushen.
Released under the MIT license.
summary: Create a beautifully simple website in under 10 minutes.
title: Academic: the website builder for Hugo

content:
R Markdown This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com.
You can embed an R code chunk like this:
summary(cars) ## speed dist ## Min. : 4.0 Min. : 2.00 ## 1st Qu.:12.0 1st Qu.: 26.00 ## Median :15.0 Median : 36.00 ## Mean :15.4 Mean : 42.98 ## 3rd Qu.:19.0 3rd Qu.: 56.00 ## Max. :25.0 Max. :120.00 fit <- lm(dist ~ speed, data = cars) fit ## ## Call: ## lm(formula = dist ~ speed, data = cars) ## ## Coefficients: ## (Intercept) speed ## -17.579 3.932  Including Plots You can also embed plots. See Figure 1 for example:
par(mar = c(0, 1, 0, 1)) pie( c(280, 60, 20), c('Sky', 'Sunny side of pyramid', 'Shady side of pyramid'), col = c('#0292D8', '#F7EA39', '#C4B632'), init.angle = -50, border = NA )  Figure 1: A fancy pie chart.

summary(cars) ## speed dist ## Min. : 4.0 Min. : 2.00 ## 1st Qu.:12.0 1st Qu.: 26.00 ## Median :15.0 Median : 36.00 ## Mean :15.4 Mean : 42.98 ## 3rd Qu.

title: An example conference paper

content:
Introduction Snowshoe hares experience population fluctuations approximately every 8-11 years1. This document explores the population dynamics of hares tagged in Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest, Alaska between 1998 and 2012. It shows how the abundance has changed, and compares the average weight of hares in the years of lowest and highest abundance.
Figure 1. Snowshoe hare, Lepus americanus. Photo Credit: National Park Service (source)
 Figure 2. Location of Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest, approximately 20 km southwest of Fairbanks, Alaska. Map Credit: Bonanza Creek LTER (source)
  Initial Data Wrangling This section contains the code used to read-in and manipulate the dataset provided by the Bonanza Creek Long Term Ecological Research Program for the subsequent visualizations and analyses.
Note: This dataset includes information about the number of hares tagged in Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest. For the sake of this document, it will be assumed that the number of hares tagged translates directly to the size of the overall population.
# Attach Packages library(tidyverse) library(janitor) library(lubridate) library(kableExtra) # Read in data, initial wrangling to select necessary columns hare <- read_csv("showshoe_lter.csv") %>% select(date, sex, age, weight, b_key, grid) %>% mutate(date = mdy(date), year = year(date), month = month(date)) # Create data frame to see population change over time yearly_timeline <- hare %>% group_by(year) %>% summarize( count = n(), avg_wt = mean(weight, na.rm = TRUE))  Visualization Snowshoe hares experience population fluctuations every 8-11 years1. Figure 1 illustrates this concept by showing the annual abundances of hares tagged in Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest from 1998-2012. Populations were high in 1999 (nearly 400 hares tagged), but decreased drastically to a low of 29 in 2002. Following this low, the population gradually increased even higher - by 2009, there were 439 hares taggged.
# Use ggplot to create a graph showing changes in annual abundance ggplot(data = yearly_timeline) + # use data frame from previous tab geom_path(aes(x = year, y = count), color = "red")+ scale_x_continuous(limits = c(1998, 2012), # set limits to x and y axis breaks = c(1998:2012), expand = c(0,.5)) + scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 500), expand = c(0,0))+ labs( # add reader-friendly labels y = "Number of hares trapped", x = "year") + theme_classic() # simple theme Figure 3. Annual abundances of tagged snowshoe hares in the Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest from 1998 to 2012.
 Statistical Comparison # Data frame to compare just the weights weight <- hare %>% filter(year %in% c(2002,2009)) %>% select(year, weight) # Look at the data to see how they are distributed # ggplot(data = weight, aes(x = weight)) + # geom_histogram()+ # facet_wrap(~year, scales = "free") # Lack of data (because lack of hares) in 2002 - not as nicely distributed but still probably OK # ggplot(data = weight, aes(sample = weight)) + # geom_qq()+ # facet_wrap(~year) #Since the majority seem normal, will still do a two-sample t-test to compare means. weight_2002 <- weight %>% filter(year == "2002") weight_2009 <- weight %>% filter(year == "2009") weight_t <- t.test(weight_2009$weight, weight_2002$weight) # Alternative for non-parametric data would be the Mann-Whitney U (just try out of curiosity) - compares medians weight_rank <- wilcox.test(weight_2002$weight, weight_2009$weight) # Both are insignificant results - meaning that there isn't a significant difference in the means or medians # Create data frame "diff" to compare lowest abundance (2002) to highest (2009) diff <- hare %>% filter(year %in% c(2002, 2009)) %>% group_by(year) %>% summarize( "Abundance" = n(), "Average Weight (g)" = mean(weight, na.rm = TRUE)) %>% pivot_longer("Abundance":"Average Weight (g)", names_to = "metric", values_to = "value") %>% pivot_wider(id_cols = metric, names_from = year, values_from = value) %>% rename(y2002 = "2002") %>% # Rename for friendlier calculations in subsequent steps rename(y2009 = "2009") %>% mutate(pct_diff = round(((y2009-y2002)/y2002)*100, 1)) %>% # calculate percent difference mutate(pct_diff = paste(pct_diff, "%", sep = "")) %>% # add "%" to those calculated values mutate_if(is.numeric, format, digits = 1, nsmall = 0) # restrict number of decimal places # Use kableExtra to make a nicely-formatted table kable(diff, col.names = c("", "2002", "2009", "Percent Increase")) %>% kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover"), full_width = F) %>% add_header_above(c("Table 1: Extreme fluctuations in the snowshoe hare population in Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest, Alaska" = 4))   Table 1: Extreme fluctuations in the snowshoe hare population in Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest, Alaska      2002  2009  Percent Increase      Abundance  38  491  1192.1%    Average Weight (g)  1202  1338  11.3%     Examining the abundance of hares over time showed that the population declined to an extreme low in 2002, but increased by 1192% to a new peak in 2009 (Figure 1, Table 1). The average weight of the hares increased slightly from 2002 to 2009 (11%), but the difference is insignificant (two sample t-test, t(36.28) = 1.9, p = 0.066).
 Citations and Additional Exploratory Code Kielland K., F. S. Chapin, R. W. Ruess. 2017. Snowshoe hare physical data in Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest: 1999-Present. Environmental Data Initiative. https://doi.org/10.6073/pasta/03dce4856d79b91557d8e6ce2cbcdc14. Dataset accessed 1/30/2020.  # Exploratory Code Not Used for Final Document # Examine and visualize monthly fluctuations in hare abundance monthly_timeline <- hare %>% group_by(month) %>% summarize( count = n(), avg_wt = mean(weight, na.rm = TRUE)) ggplot(data = monthly_timeline) + geom_point(aes(x = month, y = count)) + geom_line(aes(x = month, y = avg_wt)) # What if we follow weights of individual hares through time? individual <- hare %>% filter(!is.na(weight), !is.na(b_key)) %>% group_by(b_key) %>% summarize( count = n() # There are 9 that have been seen and weighed at least 15x ) %>% arrange(-count) %>% head(9) weights <- hare %>% filter(b_key %in% individual$b_key & !is.na(weight)) %>% mutate(id = as.factor(b_key)) ggplot(data = weights) + geom_path(aes(x = date, y = weight, color = id)) paletteer, tsibble, feasts, fable, fabletools, forecast, and mapview
summary:
Introduction Snowshoe hares experience population fluctuations approximately every 8-11 years1. This document explores the population dynamics of hares tagged in Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest, Alaska between 1998 and 2012. It shows how the abundance has changed, and compares the average weight of hares in the years of lowest and highest abundance.
Figure 1. Snowshoe hare, Lepus americanus. Photo Credit: National Park Service (source)
 Figure 2. Location of Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest, approximately 20 km southwest of Fairbanks, Alaska.
title: A case study in population fluctuations: snowshoe hares in Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest, Alaska

summary: Cori Lopazanski
title: Data Projects

content:
Introduction This document explores the relationship between various environmental variables for 224 different countries. It will use principal component analysis to illustrate how characteristics like elevation, rainfall, and amount of cropland relate to each other at global scale.
About the data: this document uses data compiled and provided by @zanter_venter, who synthesized country-level statistics using the Google Earth Engine. Data can be found here.
 Data Analysis # Attach packages library(tidyverse) library(janitor) library(ggfortify) # Read in the world environment data: world_data <- read_csv("world_env_vars.csv") %>% select(elevation, cropland_cover, tree_canopy_cover, rain_mean_annual, temp_mean_annual, cloudiness) %>% rename("Elevation" = elevation, # Rename variables for plot label friendliness later "Cropland Cover" = cropland_cover, "Tree Canopy Cover" = tree_canopy_cover, "Mean Annual Rainfall" = rain_mean_annual, "Mean Annual Temperature" = temp_mean_annual, "Cloudiness" = cloudiness) # Evaluate missing data situation # summary(world_data) # None of the chosen variables have too many NAs (11 is max) compared to data set - will drop those world_data <- world_data %>% drop_na() # PConduct pca and save, scale = TRUE to convert to similar scales world_pca <- prcomp(world_data, scale = TRUE) # Use ggfortify to make a biplot autoplot(world_pca, colour = NA, loadings.colour = "forestgreen", # change color of eigenvectors loadings.label = TRUE, loadings.label.size = 3, loadings.label.colour = "black", loadings.label.repel = TRUE) + theme_minimal()+ scale_y_continuous(limits = c(-0.2, 0.2), expand = c(0,0)) + # set limits to scale of x and y axis scale_x_continuous(limits = c(-0.2, 0.2), expand = c(0,0)) Figure 1. Biplot resulting from principal component anlaysis conducted on world environmental data. Green arrows indicate strength and relationship of variables labeled.
 Summary  Elevation and cropland cover are highly positively correlated with each other Mean annual temperature is negatively correlated with elevation and cropland cover Mean annual rainfall, canopy cover, and cloudiness are positively correllated with each other and minimally correlated with the other three variables

title: Examining global environmental data with principal component analysis

title: Landing Page

content:
Introduction Amphibian populations have been declining for over half a century1, with more than 32% of global populations currently threatened2. Habitat loss and fragmentation are among the biggest threats to these fragile populations, which require particular temperatures and levels of moisture to survive3. Clear-cut logging, in particular, has been shown to increase sedimentation in streams, which negatively impacts larval amphibians3. Monitoring efforts have been implemented to assess how activities like clear-cutting affect salmonid populations, including the Aquatic Vertebrate Population Study within the H.J. Andrews Forest Long Term Ecological Research Program (HJA LTER), which monitors the threatened Pacific giant salamander (Dicamptodon tenebrosus) among other species. Here, we examine the distribution of Pacific giant salamanders in a section of forest that was clear-cut for logging in 1963 compared to a nearby 500 year old coniferous forest in Mack Creek, Oregon. Restoration efforts are sometimes used to attempt to convert habitats from a degraded state back to their pre-disturbance condition, typically by creating pools or increasing habitat complexity4. Understanding how the distribution of Pacific giant salamanders changes in different habitats can help guide restoration efforts.
Figure 1. Pacific giant salamander, Dicamptodon tenebrosus. Photographer: Joel Sartore, National Geographic Photographer (source)
  Figure 2. Video of Pacific giant salamander. These are some of the only amphibians known to make vocalizations. Provided by YouTube user: MFWestphal (source)
 Data and Methods As part of an effort to monitor population trends of aquatic vertebrates in the H.J. Andrews Experimental Forest, data on annual abundances, weights, forest section location, and habitat preferences of the Pacific giant salamander have been collected by researchers with the Andrews Forest Long Term Ecological research site since 19935. Mack Creek runs through sections of both old growth and historically clear-cut forest and provides three primary types of habitat for aquatic organisms (pools, side-channels, and cascades). 150m stretches of the creek are divided into contiguous 50m sections, which were netted at each end. Observations for aquatic vertebrates were acquired via two-pass electrofishing, followed by subsequent measurement of body dimensions and weight for all captured individuals.
We compared annual abundances since 1993, and habitat preferences and weight differences in 2017 for Pacific giant salamanders in old growth and clear cut sections of forest. We used a Chi-square test to assess salamander habitat preferences within forest sections, a two-sample t-test test to compare mean weights by forest section, and a one-way ANOVA to compare mean weights of salamanders across the three primary habitat types. For all statistical tests, we used a significance level of \(\alpha\) = 0.05. All data preparation and analyses were completed using R software (version 3.6.1) and RStudio (version 1.2.5001).
Figure 3. Map of H. J. Andrews Experimental Forest with associated streams. Streams are depicted as blue lines and sample locations as green circles. This report focuses on salamanders found in Mack Creek. Picture credit: Sashka Warner. (source)
  Results Pacific giant salamander abundance over time Trends in Pacific giant salamander abundance were compared for the clear cut and old growth sections of Mack Creek from 1993 to 2017 (Figure 4). Throughout 1993-2017, Pacifc giant salamander abundances observed in sections of old growth forest were consistently higher than in historically clear-cut sections, with exceptions to this trend in 1994 and 2014-2017. Both populations show a marked increase in abundance following 2001 and 2014, as well as a sharp decline in 2011. Overall, populations of salamanders increased from 1993 to 2017 by 154% in the old growth section, and 192% in the clear cut section.
Figure 4. Annual abundances of the Pacific giant salamander in two standard reaches of Mack Creek in the H. J. Andrews Experimental Forest from 1993 -2017. Salamanders were counted in a reach running through a section of old growth forest (blue line) and a section of historically clear-cut forest (red line).
 Salamander habitat preference within old growth vs clear cut forest sections   Table 1: Proportions of giant salamanders in different channel classifications observed in two sections of Mack Creek      Clear Cut  Old Growth      Cascade  247 (67.1%)  201 (62.8%)    Pool  31 (8.4%)  45 (14.1%)    Side-Channel  90 (24.5%)  74 (23.1%)     Channels that make up Pacific giant salamander habitat are often classified into three different areas: cascades, pools, and side channels. Proportions of salamanders in each channel classification were compared for the old growth and clear cut sections of Mack Creek (Table 1).
There is not a significant effect of forest section (old growth or clear cut) on where salamanders are found in the channel (\(\chi\)2(2) = 5.54, p = 0.06). There are similar proportions of salamanders found in each of the three channel classifications in both the clear-cut and old growth sections of forest (Table 1).
 Comparison of salamander weight by forest section and channel classification In addition to abundance, examining salamander weight can yield more information about the size distribution of the populations in the different forest sections and channel classifications.
There was no significant difference in mean salamander weight in 2017 for the old growth compared to the clear cut section of forest (two sample t-test, t(692.79) = -1.67, p = 0.096). Thus, weight information was combined for the two sections to examine size distributions across the diffferent channel classifications (Figure 5).
Figure 5.  Distributions for Giant Pacific Salamander mass (g) are displayed (violins) for habitat type, pooled for old growth and clear cut sections of forest. Mean masses (black dots) \(\pm\) standard error (error bars) are displayed for each habitat type.
Mean weights of Pacific giant salamanders did differ significantly between pools and side channels (one-way ANOVA with post-hoc Tukey’s HSD: F\(_{2,684}\) = 4.22, p = 0.015). Mean weights for individuals from cascades did not differ significantly from the other two habitat types (Figure 5). The average weight for populations residing in pools (9.3 \(\pm\) 1.56 g) was 63.79% more than that of populations observed in side-channels (5.68 \(\pm\) 0.65 g). Due to large within group variation of salamander weights in each habitat type, an alternative metric – population medians, for instance – may lend to a more meaningful and accurate comparison across these groups. This could be achieved by using a rank-based test, such as a Mann-Whitney U test.
  Summary  From 1993-2017, overall Pacific giant salamander abundances increased in both old growth and historically clear cut sections of forest, by 154% and 192% respectively (Figure 4). Forest section (old growth vs clear cut) did not significantly affect the habitat type (pool, cascade, or side-channel) in which salamnders were found (Table 1). There is no significant difference in mean salamander weight in 2017 for the old growth compared to the clear cut section of forest. In 2017, the mean weight of salamanders residing in pools was significantly greater than that of populations in side channels (Figure 5).   References Houlahan, J., et al. “Quantitative evidence for global amphibian population declines.” Nature 404 (2000): 752-755.
 Stuart, S. N., et al. “Status and trends of amphibian declines and extinctions worldwide.” Science 306 (2004): 1783-1786.
 Johnston, B. and Frid, L. “Clearcut logging restricts the movements of terrestrial Pacific giant salamanders (Dicamptodon tenebrosus Good)” Canadian Journal of Zoology 80 (2011): 2170-2177.

 Gregory S. V. 2016. Aquatic Vertebrate Population Study in Mack Creek, Andrews Experimental Forest, 1987 to present. Environmental Data Initiative. https://doi.org/10.6073/pasta/5de64af9c11579266ef20da2ff32f702. Dataset accessed 11/19/2019.

Habitat loss and fragmentation are among the biggest threats to these fragile populations, which require particular temperatures and levels of moisture to survive3. Clear-cut logging, in particular, has been shown to increase sedimentation in streams, which negatively impacts larval amphibians3. Monitoring efforts have been implemented to assess how activities like clear-cutting affect salmonid populations, including the Aquatic Vertebrate Population Study within the H.
title: Population characteristics of the Pacific giant salamander in old growth vs clear cut forests

content:
Introduction Marine Protected Areas (MPAs) have been established along the California coast to protect coastal species and their habitat through regulation of fishing and other potentially harmful human activities1. Monitoring efforts have been implemented to assess the effectiveness of these MPAs by comparing population characteristics of species inside and outside of the protected areas2. One such effort, undertaken by the Santa Barbara Coastal Long Term Ecological Research (SBC LTER) program, conducts yearly monitoring of kelp forest species in the Santa Barbara Channel inside and outside of MPAs. Within the Santa Barbara Channel, the California Spiny Lobster (Panulirus interruptus) is currently a species of interest, as it provides a lucrative fishery but also serves an important role in maintaining kelp forest ecosystems through predation of sea urchins3. Without predatory regulation, sea urchins can reach abundances high enough to decimate kelp populations and induce unfavorable ecosystem shifts from kelp forests to urchin barrens4. Excessive fishing of other species of lobster has been implicated in causing subsequent overgrazing of macroalgal communities by sea urchins5, 6. Here, we assess impacts of fishing pressure on population characteristics of the California Spiny lobster from 2012-2018.
Figure 1: California Spiny Lobster, Panulirus interruptus. Photographer: Joel Sartore, National Geographic Photographer (source)
  Data and methods Data for California spiny lobster abundance and size were collected and provided by researchers with the Santa Barbara Coastal Long-Term Ecological Research Program (SBC LTER)7. Divers collected annual estimates from 2012-2018 at five long-term kelp forest sites. Two sites (Naples and Isla Vista) are located in designated MPAs, which were created on 2012-01-01. The other three sites (Mohawk Reef, Carpinteria, and Arroyo Quemado) are located in unprotected areas. Estimates were collected annually in late summer, before the start of the fishing season, by counting lobsters to quantify abundance and visually estimating the carapace length (mm) for size information across a 40-meter transect at the five sites.
Changes in annual lobster abundance over time were examined for each site by comparing the total lobster count for each year from 2012-2018. Size distributions were examined by comparing the size composition (mm) of the lobsters measured at each site in 2012 and in 2018. Mean lobster size was compared for lobsters measured in MPAs versus unprotected waters in 2012 and in 2018 using two-sample t-tests (\(\alpha\) = 0.5 throughout). For more information on site and data collection methods, see metadata.
All data preparation and analyses were completed using R software (version 3.6.1) and RStudio (version 1.2.5001).
 Results Trends in annual lobster abundance following MPA creation in 2012 The Isla Vista and Naples sites were declared MPAs in 2012, effectively eliminating fishing pressure for spiny lobsters in those areas. The trends in total annual lobster abundance for those two sites, as well as the three other unprotected sites, were compared for 2012-2018 (Fig. 2).
Figure 2. Total annual abundance of CA spiny lobsters for 5 sites in the Santa Barbara Channel from 2012 to 2018. Solid lines indicate sites within marine protected areas (Isla Vista and Naples) and dashed lines indicate sites in unprotected areas (Carpinteria, Mohawk, and Arroyo Quemado).
All sites have similar annual lobster abundance in 2012 and show an overall increase by 2018, but the two sites in Marine Protected Areas (Isla Vista and Naples) show a much greater increase than the sites in unprotected areas (Arroyo Quemado, Carpinteria, and Mohawk). From 2012 to 2018, annual lobster abundance at the Isla Vista and Naples sites increased by 3538% and 4866%, respectively. Percent increases in annual abundance were much smaller at the unprotected sites: though Carpinteria showed a drastic increase from 2015-2017, the overall increase in annual abundance was an order of magnitude smaller than the MPA sites (339%), and the other unprotected sites had even smaller changes at 42% and 98% (Arroyo Quemado and Mohawk, respectively).
 Shifts in lobster size distributions from 2012 to 2018 Figure 3. Size distributions of the California Spiny Lobster at 5 sites in the Santa Barbara Channel (Naples and Isla Vista = within MPA; Mohawk, Arroyo Quemado, and Carpinteria = outside of MPA) in 2012 (red) and 2018 (blue). Sizes are measured as carapace length in mm.
Both sites within MPAs (Naples and Isla Vista) showed increases in lobster size distribution from 2012 to 2018 (Fig. 3). Size distributions of lobsters in the non-MPA sites (Mohawk reef, Carpinteria, and Arroyo Quemado) appear relatively similar in both 2012 and 2018.
 Statistical comparisons for CA spiny lobster monitoring efforts Immediately following establishment of the MPAs in 2012, mean lobster size at sites inside MPAs was significantly different from that observed for lobsters in unprotected waters (two-sample t-test, t(42.09) = -3.25, p = 0.002), with lobsters measured inside MPAs roughly 10% smaller (Table 1). By 2018, mean lobster size inside MPAs still differed significantly from unprotected waters (two-sample t-test, t(1239.51) = 7.31, p < 0.001), however it was roughly 5% greater in the MPA sites.
Lobster size inside MPA sites increased significantly by an average of 15% from 2012 to 2018 (two-sample t-test, t(32.5) = -4.69, p < 0.001)), while lobsters observed outside of MPAs showed a marginal non-significant decrease in mean size over the same time period (two-sample t-test, t(296.01) = 1.33, p = 0.18).
Table 1. California Spiny Lobster size statistics for monitoring efforts inside and outside of MPAs in the Santa Barbara Channel for 2012 and 2018.   Protection  Mean Size (mm)  Standard Deviation  Sample Size     2012    MPA  67.37500  12.15425  32    Non-MPA  74.92462  12.41412  199   2018    MPA  77.56672  11.70341  1244    Non-MPA  73.61996  10.09438  561       Summary  Lobster abundances have increased from 2012 to 2018, with sites in MPAs showing much greater proportional increases than sites in unprotected areas (Fig. 2) Size of lobsters in marine protected areas has increased from 2012 to 2018 (Fig. 3) There is a significant difference in the size of lobsters in MPAs compared to unprotected waters (Table 1)   References “California Marine Protected Areas (MPAs)”. California Department of Fish and Wildlife, State of California, 2019. https://www.wildlife.ca.gov/Conservation/Marine/MPAs
 “MPA Monitoring.” California MPAs. http://californiampas.org/mpa-monitoring
 Tegner, M. J., and L. A. Levin. “Spiny lobsters and sea urchins: analysis of a predator-prey interaction.” Journal of Experimental Marine Biology and Ecology 73.2 (1983): 125-150.
 Ling, S. D., et al. “Global regime shift dynamics of catastrophic sea urchin overgrazing.” Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society B: Biological Sciences 370.1659 (2015): 20130269.
 Breen, P. A., and K. H. Mann. “Changing lobster abundance and the destruction of kelp beds by sea urchins.” Marine Biology 34.2 (1976): 137-142.
 Wharton, W. G., and K. H. Mann. “Relationship between destructive grazing by the sea urchin, Strongylocentrotus droebachiensis, and the abundance of American lobster, Homarus americanus, on the Atlantic coast of Nova Scotia.” Canadian Journal of Fisheries and Aquatic Sciences 38.11 (1981): 1339-1349.
 Reed D. 2019. SBC LTER: Reef: Abundance, size and fishing effort for California Spiny Lobster (Panulirus interruptus), ongoing since 2012. Environmental Data Initiative. https://doi.org/10.6073/pasta/a593a675d644fdefb736750b291579a0. Dataset accessed 11/14/2019.
summary: Introduction Marine Protected Areas (MPAs) have been established along the California coast to protect coastal species and their habitat through regulation of fishing and other potentially harmful human activities1. Monitoring efforts have been implemented to assess the effectiveness of these MPAs by comparing population characteristics of species inside and outside of the protected areas2. One such effort, undertaken by the Santa Barbara Coastal Long Term Ecological Research (SBC LTER) program, conducts yearly monitoring of kelp forest species in the Santa Barbara Channel inside and outside of MPAs.
title: Spiny lobster size and abundance along the Santa Barbara coast

summary: Add page description
title: Teaching

content:
Introduction Steelhead are a fascinating group of fishes. They are the same species as freshwater rainbow trout (Oncorhynchus mykiss), but exhibit the salmon-esque behavior of swimming upstream from the ocean to spawn in the rivers where they were born. Interestingly, some even return back to the ocean after spawning - something salmon don’t even do! Monitoring populations of these special fish is important as they face increased threats due to climate change. This document explores time series data of the passage of steelhead across the Bonneville Dam in Oregon from 1940-2019.
For an interesting read on the hot debate of if a steelhead should be considered a salmon or trout, check out this article.
 Figure 1. Video of Bonneville Dam Fish Ladder. Provided by YouTube user: Pacific NW (source)
Data was retrieved from Columbia Basin Research DART (Data Access in Real Time), affiliated with the University of Washington. Counts are reported for fish crossing the Bonneville Dam fish ladder each day, either through live counts or video observations1. Data can be accessed here.
 Initial setup & data wrangling # Attach necessary packages library(tidyverse) library(lubridate) library(janitor) library(paletteer) library(tsibble) library(fable) library(fabletools) library(feasts) # Read in data, clean up a bit! fish <- read_csv("cbr_fish_passage_bonneville_allyrs_steelhead.csv") %>% clean_names() %>% mutate(day_month = mm_dd) %>% # R doesn't love the mm-dd naming unite("date", "year":"mm_dd", sep = "-") %>% # Combine year and month-day column mutate(date = ydm(date), year = year(date), month = month(date, label = TRUE), year_month = yearmonth(date)) %>% #yearmonth class important for ts seasonplot filter(year %in% c(1940:2019)) # only observations from 1940-2019 # Create a subset totaling the number of fish counted each month fish_month <- fish %>% group_by(year_month) %>% summarize(total = sum(value, na.rm = TRUE)) %>% mutate(year = year(year_month), month = month(year_month, label = TRUE), fish = "steelhead") # Coerce the fish_month data to a tsibble, which is friendlier for working with time series data fish_ts <- as_tsibble(fish_month, key = fish, index = year_month) # Look at it! #autoplot(fish_ts) #gg_subseries(fish_ts)  Exploring time series of steelhead passage: daily, monthly, and annually Counts of the number of steelhead crossing the Bonneville Dam each day show potential seasonality in fluctuations of the population (Fig. 2). There seems to be significant variation between years, as well as a general increasing trend between 1940 and 2019. This section will examine these trends more closely.
# Basic plot of daily time series data ggplot(data = fish) + geom_point(aes(x = date, y = value, color = year), show.legend = FALSE) + theme_classic() + labs( x = NULL, y = "Number of steelhead counted per day") + scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 35000), expand = c(0,0)) + # set y axis limits scale_color_paletteer_c("ggthemes::Blue")  Figure 2. Time series data of steelhead crossings for the Bonneville Dam from 1940-2019.
Closer examination reveals consistent seasonality in the timing of steelhead passage (Fig. 3) The highest number of steelhead counted is typically in the late summer months, usually around August, and has not shifted much between 1940 and 2019.
# Create a season plot of a subset of the data to examine shift in the timing of fish passage ggplot(data = fish_month %>% filter(year %in% c(1940, 1960, 1980, 2000, 2019)), aes(x = month, y = total, group = year)) + geom_line(aes(color = year), show.legend = FALSE) + facet_wrap(~ year, ncol = 1, scales = "free", strip.position = "right")+ labs(x = NULL, y = "number of steelhead counted each month")+ scale_color_paletteer_c("ggthemes::Blue")+ theme_classic() Figure 3. Timing of steelhead passage across the Bonneville Dam in 1940, 1960, 1980, 2000, 2019.
Examining monthly counts for all years confirms the consistency in this timing (Fig. 4) but also highlights the interannual variation in the size of the population. The population peaks in late summer each year, but at very differrent levels.
# Use gg_season to make a more traditional season-plot gg_season(fish_ts) + labs(x = NULL, y = "number of steelhead counted") + scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 250000), expand = c(0,0)) + theme_classic()+ scale_color_paletteer_c("ggthemes::Blue", direction = 1, labels = c("1940", "1960", "1980", "2000", "2019")) Figure 4. Passage of steelhead across the Bonneville Dam. Shades of blue transition from light to dark over time - early years (1940s) are shown in light blue, and later years (2010s) in darker blues.
There is significant interannual variability in the number of steelhead crossing the dam, as seen by the many peaks and troughs (Fig. 5 solid line), however this variability also follows a larger trend: the population saw significant increases in the late 1990s and early 2000s, but has since began to decline (Fig 5 dashed line and shaded area).
fish_year <- fish_ts %>% index_by(annual = ~year(.)) %>% summarize( avg_amount = mean(total)) ggplot(data = fish_year, aes(x = annual, y = avg_amount)) + geom_line(color = "steelblue4") + geom_smooth(color = "steelblue4", size = 0.2, linetype = "dashed", fill = "steelblue3", alpha = 0.2) + theme_classic() + labs(x = NULL, y = "annual number of steelhead") Figure 5. Annual passage of steelhead across the Bonneville Dam (solid line), overall trend using loess smoothing (dashed line), with 95% confidence intervals (shaded area).
 Citations Columbia River DART, Columbia Basin Research, University of Washington. (2019). Adult Passage Graphics & Text. Available from http://www.cbr.washington.edu/dart/query/adult_graph_text
summary: Introduction Steelhead are a fascinating group of fishes. They are the same species as freshwater rainbow trout (Oncorhynchus mykiss), but exhibit the salmon-esque behavior of swimming upstream from the ocean to spawn in the rivers where they were born. Interestingly, some even return back to the ocean after spawning - something salmon don’t even do! Monitoring populations of these special fish is important as they face increased threats due to climate change.
title: Using time series data to explore steelhead passage across the Bonneville Dam
